heading: Section A
Subheading: Indicate the following statement is true or false

Question.content: The invertebrate has very many characteristics in common, which include among others, size, structure and mode of life.

Explanation.content: False. Invertebrates are extremely diverse in size (e.g., microscopic rotifers vs. giant squid), structure (exoskeletons vs. hydrostatic skeletons), and mode of life (parasitic vs. free-living). They share no universal characteristics beyond lacking a vertebral column.

Question.content: All protozoa are parasites.

Explanation.content: False. While some protozoa are parasitic (e.g., Plasmodium), many are free-living (e.g., Amoeba proteus in freshwater) or symbiotic (e.g., gut-dwelling Trichonympha in termites).

Question.content: Climate do form gamete.

Explanation.content: False. This statement appears to be a typographical error. If referring to Climacostomum (a ciliate protozoan), it reproduces via conjugation (genetic exchange) but does not form true gametes. Gamete formation is typical of sexual reproduction in multicellular organisms.

Question.content: The subclass Spirotrichia consist of ciliates, which have sparse body cilia and conspicuous oral ciliature, winding clockwise.

Explanation.content: True. Spirotrichs (e.g., Stylonychia) are characterized by reduced body cilia and prominent oral cilia arranged in spiral, clockwise patterns for filter-feeding.

Question.content: Adult sponges are sessile.

Explanation.content: True. Adult sponges (Porifera) are permanently attached to substrates (rocks, coral). Only their larval stages are motile, using cilia to disperse.

Question.content: Choanocytes are peculiar to sponges among animals with multicellular somatic organization.

Explanation.content: True. Choanocytes (collar cells) are unique to sponges. Their flagella create water currents, and microvilli trap food particles—a synapomorphy of Porifera.

Question.content: Sponges have reduced sensory organs.

Explanation.content: True. Sponges lack true nervous or sensory organs. They respond to stimuli via individual cell reactions (e.g., closing ostia in response to sediment).

Question.content: During embryonic development the micromeres overgrow the megameres.

Explanation.content: True. In sponges, micromeres (small cells) proliferate and envelop megameres (large yolk-rich cells) during parenchymula larval development—a process called epiboly.

Question.content: The two structural forms seen among cnidarians are polyps and medusa.

Explanation.content: True. Cnidarians exhibit alternation of generations: polyps (sessile, tubular; e.g., coral) and medusae (free-swimming, bell-shaped; e.g., jellyfish). Some species retain only one form.

Question.content: In the class Scyphozoa, the medusa is the dominant and conspicuous individual in the life cycle.

Explanation.content: True. Scyphozoans (true jellyfish) prioritize the medusa stage. Their polyps (scyphistomae) are small and transient, budding off medusae asexually.

Question.content: The body of the ctenophores is divided into equal sections by eight ciliated bands called comb rows.

Explanation.content: True. Ctenophores (comb jellies) have eight meridional comb rows made of fused cilia. These rows propel the animal and refract light, creating iridescence.

Question.content: In ctenophores, the outer epidermis lack nematocysts.

Explanation.content: True. Ctenophores capture prey using colloblasts (sticky cells), not nematocysts. Nematocysts are exclusive to cnidarians.

Question.content: Cnidarians have no anus.

Explanation.content: True. Cnidarians have a blind gut (single opening serving as mouth/anus). Waste is expelled orally after digestion in the gastrovascular cavity.

Question.content: Monogenetic trematodes have only a single host in their life cycle.

Explanation.content: True. Monogeneans (e.g., Gyrodactylus) are ectoparasites of fish gills/skin, requiring only one host. Contrast with digeneans (e.g., liver flukes) that need multiple hosts.

Question.content: Cnidarians are distinguished from the ctenophores by being primarily radially symmetrical about their oral axis.

Explanation.content: False. Both cnidarians and ctenophores exhibit radial symmetry. The key distinction is that ctenophores are biradial (with two planes of symmetry) and possess colloblasts instead of nematocysts.

Question.content: Nemerteans are the only acoelomates to possess a true circulating system.

Explanation.content: True. Nemerteans (ribbon worms) have a closed circulatory system with blood vessels, unique among acoelomates. Their rhynchocoel (proboscis cavity) acts as a hydrostatic skeleton.

heading: Section B
Subheading: Circle only the letters of the answers which will make the following statements read correctly. Some statements have more than one correct answer.

Question.content: The subkingdom Eumetazoa consists of the following grades:

Explanation.content:
Eumetazoa has two main groups:

  • Radiate - Animals with radial symmetry like jellyfish
  • Bilateria - Animals with bilateral symmetry like humans
  • The other options are not real classification terms

Question.content: Asexual reproduction in protozoa occurs in any of the following ways:

Explanation.content:
Protozoa can reproduce asexually in all these ways:

  • Binary fission - Splitting into two equal cells
  • Budding - Growing a small copy that detaches
  • Multiple fission - Making many cells at once
  • Endodyogeny - Internal growth of offspring

Question.content: The pseudopodia seen in amoeba include:

Explanation.content:
Real types of pseudopodia (false feet) in amoebas:

  • Lobopodia - Thick, finger-like extensions
  • Filopodia - Thin, thread-like extensions
  • Axopodia - Long, stiff projections with core support
  • Reticulopodia - Net-like branching extensions
  • The last two options are made-up terms

Question.content: The outer layer of the body (ectoderm) of cnidarians consists of the following types of cells:

Explanation.content:
Correct cell types in cnidarian outer layer:

  • Myoepithelial cells - For movement and structure
  • Cnidocytes - Stinging cells
  • Sensory cells - Detect environment
  • Nerve cells - Basic nervous system
  • Note: 'Sea anemones' is an animal, not a cell type

Question.content: Cnidarians include the following:

Explanation.content:
These are all cnidarians:

  • Hydra - Small freshwater animals
  • Sea anemones - Colorful ocean creatures
  • Jellyfishes - Floating, stinging animals
  • Corals - Reef-building organisms
  • Not cnidarians: Coccidians (parasites) and flatworms

Question.content: The principal sense organs in nematodes are:

Explanation.content:
Nematodes primarily sense with:

  • Amphids - Chemosensory pits near the head
  • Phasmids - Small sensory organs near the tail
  • Other options: Papillae and setae are for touch, not primary senses

Question.content: The principal nitrogenous waste of protozoan

Explanation.content:
Ammonia is the main nitrogenous waste in protozoans because:

  • They live in aquatic environments where ammonia can easily diffuse away
  • It requires less energy to produce than urea or uric acid
  • Being small organisms, they don't need complex waste processing systems

Question.content: A small pore in the pellicle of ciliate through which insoluble matter is ejected?

Explanation.content:
The cytopyge is:

  • A dedicated 'cell anus' in ciliates like Paramecium
  • Located at a specific spot on the pellicle (cell membrane)
  • Used to expel undigested waste after food vacuole processing
  • Different from the cytostome (cell mouth) where food enters

Question.content: Typical sponges larva

Explanation.content:
Sponges typically have an amphiblastula larva which:

  • Is free-swimming and helps in dispersal
  • Has two distinct cell layers (like all sponge larvae)
  • Eventually settles and develops into an adult sponge
  • Differs from cnidarian planula larvae in structure

Question.content: Typical larva of Cnidarians

Explanation.content:
The planula larva is characteristic of cnidarians because:

  • It's a ciliated, free-swimming stage after fertilization
  • Eventually settles and develops into either a polyp or medusa form
  • Has simple tissue organization but no organs
  • Found in jellyfish, corals, and sea anemones

Question.content: Principal opening of the sponge body

Explanation.content:
The osculum is:

  • The large exit opening at the top of a sponge
  • Where filtered water exits after passing through the canal system
  • Often visible as a dark hole in sponge specimens
  • Latin for 'little mouth'

Question.content: Typical of protozoans

Explanation.content:
Protozoa are:

  • Single-celled eukaryotic organisms
  • Animal-like in their nutrition (heterotrophic)
  • Found in all aquatic environments
  • Include amoebas, paramecia, and other microorganisms

Question.content: Hind end in Amoeba

Explanation.content:
The uroid is:

  • The trailing end of an amoeba during movement
  • Often appears wrinkled or folded as pseudopodia extend forward
  • Helps in waste elimination and water balance
  • From Greek 'oura' meaning tail

Question.content: A parasite protozoon with endo-skeletal structure (axostyle)

Explanation.content:
Trichomonas is:

  • A parasitic protozoan causing human infections
  • Has an axostyle - a rigid rod-like structure for support
  • Moves using flagella
  • Causes trichomoniasis, a sexually transmitted infection

Question.content: A free living amoeba with a testa of sand grain

Explanation.content:
Difflugia is:

  • A testate (shelled) amoeba
  • Builds its test (shell) from collected sand grains
  • Common in freshwater environments
  • Extends pseudopodia through an opening in the test

Question.content: A colourless protozoa with holozoic nutrition

Explanation.content:
Paranema is:

  • A colorless flagellate protozoan
  • Exhibits holozoic nutrition (engulfs food particles)
  • Common in freshwater habitats
  • Has an anterior flagellum for movement

Question.content: Animal-like acellular organism

Explanation.content:
Protozoa are considered animal-like because:

  • They are heterotrophic (consume organic matter)
  • Lack cell walls like animal cells
  • Many are motile using flagella, cilia or pseudopodia
  • Include predators, parasites and grazers

Question.content: Green protophyta with holophytic nutrition

Explanation.content:
Euglena species:

  • Are green due to chloroplasts
  • Perform photosynthesis (holophytic nutrition)
  • Can also feed heterotrophically when light is unavailable
  • Have characteristics of both plants and animals

Question.content: Plant-like acellular organism

Explanation.content:
Prostophyta are:

  • Plant-like protists (algae)
  • Contain chlorophyll for photosynthesis
  • Often have cell walls like plants
  • Include many unicellular and colonial forms

Question.content: The ctenophores

Explanation.content:
Comb jellies are:

  • Marine animals also known as ctenophores
  • Named for their 'combs' of cilia used for swimming
  • Biradially symmetrical
  • Use sticky colloblasts to capture prey (not stinging cells)

Question.content: Mobile pharynx of rotifers

Explanation.content:
The mastax is:

  • A specialized muscular pharynx in rotifers
  • Contains hard jaw-like structures called trophi
  • Used to grind up food particles
  • Unique to rotifers among invertebrates

Question.content: Large posterior adhesive organ in monogenetic Trematodes

Explanation.content:
The opisthaptor is:

  • A posterior attachment organ in monogenetic flukes
  • Equipped with hooks or clamps for anchoring to hosts
  • Greek for 'rear holder'
  • Essential for parasites living on fish gills/skin

Question.content: The anterior regions of tapeworms

Explanation.content:
The scolex is:

  • The head region of tapeworms
  • Has suckers and sometimes hooks for attachment
  • Doesn't have a mouth (nutrients absorbed through body)
  • Connects to the neck region where new segments form
